Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Novel Computational Approaches to Address Key Design Optimization Issues for Metal Additive Manufacturing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The additive manufacturing (AM), also called 3D printing, process is now capable of manufacturing complex-shaped metal components strong enough for structural applications. The capability of AM to fabricate complex geometries removes many conventional manufacturing constraints and largely expands the design space. However, there are key current issues that are impeding the marriage between AM and topology optimization: 1) Difficulty in machining topology optimized AM components due to their highly complex shapes, and 2) Inability to optimize AM part design for residual stress and distortion. This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) research project aims at establishing a robust topology optimization technology capable of accounting for residual distortion, residual stress, and post-machining requirements for additive manufactured (AM) components. The technology developed will significantly shorten the design phase during new AM product development, which will potentially lead to wider adoption of AM by the manufacturing base in the US. The skills and knowledge the students gain through this project will prepare them for active roles in securing U.S. leadership in engineering design and advanced manufacturing for future generations.

The goal of this GOALI project is to address the aforementioned critical design issues by proposing and investigating two novel approaches. The first approach is an ultra-fast computational method based on the inherent strain theory for predicting residual stress and distortion in an AM part. The second approach is a level set feature-based topology optimization method capable of generating designs with both freeform surfaces and machining-friendly surfaces. These approaches will be developed and tested using real parts and design requirements provided by our industrial partner Aerotech. Utilizing this approach, a robust topology optimization method will be developed to optimize AM designs for residual stress, residual distortion, and post-machining requirements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Additive manufacturing (AM) (also called 3D printing) process is now capable of manufacturing complex-shaped metal components strong enough for structural applications. The capability of AM to fabricate complex geometries removes many conventional manufacturing constraints and largely expands the design space.  However, there are key current issues that are impeding the marriage between AM and topology optimization: 1) Difficulty in machining topology optimized AM components due to their highly complex shapes, and 2) Inability to optimize AM part design for residual stress and distortion.  In this project, a number of new AM oriented topology optimization methods have been formulated and demonstrated.  These methods include 1) a level set based optimization method to generate support-free design that ensure AM manufacturability; 2) a level set feature based optimization method capable of generating designs with machining-friendly surfaces whose complexity can be controlled by the designer; 3) an optimization method considering manufacturing cost; 4) incorporating of residual stress into support structure optimization and build orientation optimization via the modified inherent strain method.  Overall, the developed optimization methods are expected to drastically reduce number of printing experiments for new AM product development. The research supported by this grant has resulted in 12 published journal articles. 

The impact of this project to the discipline of design and manufacturing is significant.  This project has demonstrated that it is now possible to utilize topology optimization to design AM components that are both structurally sound and post-machining friendly.  Such technology will enable the design and manufacture of much higher performing AM products and result in wider adoption of AM process by the manufacturing industry in the US. Successful demonstration of the new topology optimization methods in this project will impact the materials science discipline by opening the opportunity to optimize the design at both the macrostructure and microstructure scales. The proposed activities for education and outreach included: 1) two new graduate courses in AM, 2) several senior design projects for undergraduate students, and 3) AM workshops for high school students. These activities aimed to provide training to students in the emerging field of AM as well as to raise the interest level of students in science and engineering, especially those from underrepresented minority groups. A postdoctoral researcher, four graduate students, and three undergraduate students working on this project were exposed to groundbreaking interdisciplinary research that encompasses AM, topology optimization, solid mechanics, and heat transfer.
